												Don't be fooled by my steam playtime, I have much longer logged on my boxed copy and still play to this day. It's a game I enjoy so much I bough a steam copy just for backup purposes.  The end of an era, it marks the last great tactical shooter on the market before this series descended into mediocrity. Nothing else since this has come close to equalling its quality of brutal, unforgiving tactics. This is a game that wears its realism on its sleeve and isn't afraid to let you drop dead from one bullet fired from a guy you couldn't even have seen coming. You move slowly and even walking throws your aim way off. Repeated autofire might as well be fired with your eyes closed. Guns feel weighty and impactful, dropping enemies in one or two torso shots.  It's harsh and doesn't feel remotely fair at times, but having smooth, flawless success in this game is more satisfying than any other shooter I've played. Unlocking all the maps requires playing through the campaign mode, where the iffy team AI and permanent injuries/death to the squad members can make things frustrating, but if you take the time to plan things out they usually go well. The game has no tolerance for the slightest mistake, for even a single corner left unchecked, and requires awareness and caution you rarely need in other games. The real fun comes with friends. Competitive modes are fine, but nothing's better than the sheer teamwork it takes to clear out a whole map in co-op. And the sheer disaster that can strike if any one of you slips up for a moment. Multiplayer no longer functions out of the box, so you'll have to take alternate methods to get it work, such as Hamachi or Tunngle, but it's well worth the effort. Still one of my favourite coop games of all time.

												Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six 3 Gold by Tom Clancy is a third game in Tom Clancy's Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six franchise. Which was realistical tactical shooter, where you would create your own plan for the level and then execute it, being excited to see how your dumb AI teammates will get slaughtered this time. And yes, it uses "one shot, one kill" system, almost. Released in in 2003 by Red Storm and Ubisoft, it also had console ports for Xbox, PS2 and Gamecube. Consoles ports were different: no planning, you command only one 4-man squad and each got few hitpoints.This is Gold, meaning that it comes with inclusion of original Raven Shield game and the first expansion pack - Athena Sword, that mostly adds few more levels, released in 2004.There also was a second expansion pack, which was almost finished (probably meaning that it just didn't go through debugging), Iron Wrath. It was released for free in 2005 on Internet anyway. Meaning that people were happy, aside from 56kb modem users. So, technical stuff. While main menu and planning phase work at 4:3 resolution, gameplay itself supports widescreen resolution. But it doesn't change FOV, so you will be seeing chubby people. But it crashes sometimes when you change between planning phase and execution phase. So always save your plans!Expansion packs are a bit weird in that they will not play their new sounds, that are briefing voice acting and new sounds for new weapons. To fix that, you will have to go to mods folder, find folder of needed expansion pack, and then copy "Sounds" folder from there to the root directory of the game.You also will have problems installing free Iron Wrath, as installer will not recognise Rainbow Six for what it is. To fix that just check Steam Guides. In nutshell, you will have to create new key in Registry where retail version of a game keeps all the needed info about itself. You don't have to screw the system itself, don't worry.As for multiplayer, well, you could play in either coop or competive. It used old Ubi service, but as of now, multiplayer is technically dead. I heard that at some point you was required to use UPlay account instead, but it didn't work for me.EDIT: Because turns out that my actual login, that is email, is way too long for the game. HA!In this game you play as anybody of Rainbow Six squad, the point of which is to make terrorist think that they are dealing with six pony-loving hippies, only to be met with eight aim-botting hard-try top operatives. But because it's a top secret squad and it's actions are written off as actions of special forces of whatever country they are in, the shock tactic of the name just never works. Just use flashbangs for that.Well, in this part you are dealing with neo-nazi terrorists who love taking hostages, listen to briefing and watch occasional cutscenes that make you feel good and even heroic for a job well done. Which is nice. It has ending video, so that's enough.Another thing to note is that Rainbow Six is full of only top-top-top people, only the best individuals from separate parts of world. And then, after collecting them all, no one bothered to teach them how to work as a team. The only thing they ever learned is that they are supposed to walk in a line. And even then it can go wrong in small hallways, where a leader of a line will turn around and start pushing the tail out, as it refused to turn around, until his heavily armored butt slides out from the doorway and gets filled with bullets, while you scream at the screen in observation mode. Good bullets. Shiny, sturdy, can survive from -50 to +50 degrees of temperature. Must be 7.62x39mm ones. A bit outdated, but good bullets indeed, tactical-realism fans approve.No, really, I got to see that few times.But really, AI in single-player game can do a lot of things to sabotage the fact that game relies on squad-based tactics.And well, let's say that Rainbow Six 3 isn't as best ever as fans tend to call it.Or at least it didn't age well.And when I say "didn't age well", what I mean is "SWAT 4 came out". Which was not only more tactical, but implented proper AI teammates. No planning phase though.At least graphics and music in this game are still nice. Even got ambient music sometimes playing during mission and such. And ragdolls look funny nowdays, just crashing onto floor. Blam.Anyway, since fans of tactical-realistical games always brag about such games and on question "what is tactical exactly?" they answer only "ummmm... you are too stupid to get", here is what you get to expect: Abuse leaning around corners when you are controlling a soldier; Abuse the aimbotness of AI teammates and place them in such way that no one walks behind them; Throw smoke grenade to become invinsible for AI; Try to come into difficult room from few directions with different teams. Those four rules is what makes this game. And planning.You get into mission and first thing you get is briefing. After that, you are going to set up a plan. And oh boy, that's the main feature of the early games of franchise, as you get to put waypoints for up to three teams. You can also coordinate them together by setting go-codes. Tell them to throw grenade or breach the door. Actually, you can either try to beat level with no plan like generic realistical shooter, use pre-made one, use pre-made one and edit if neccersary or just make up a whole new one. And it's just awesome that you can make the map play out the way you want. Until you will find out that AI can't open door slightly and throw grenade in, like players. Or bounce grenade at the wall, limiting the usage of flashbang. Or that they have tendency to never stop at waypoints and fire full-automatic while walking. Or that they will never decide to wait for enemy come out if they hear "huh, that's strange". Or the way you can't order them to throw smoke grenade down the tunnel in the third mission, so it's only up to player. Or just find out that some tasks AI does really badly.In other words, while it DOES require tactical planning, but for dumb AI. Through trial-and-error of execution you will find what AI does best and judging by this you will build your plan for dummies. Which takes away some enjoyment.If you try to pull something clever in this, you will have to do dirty job with your own hands. And even if you build a good plan, there is a bit of randomness on placement of some terrorists, so it can sometimes go wrong anyway.After that, you set up a squad, pulling 8 members for a job and separating them into teams. While wondering what's the point of Demos, who just make some objectives complete few seconds faster, and recons types. After that you look at huge list of samey weapons that you don't care about, pick the strongest/favourite assault rifle and put silencer onto it, as there is no real tactical choice. Unless sniper rifle. Then you look over some more useless devices, including multiplayer-only, which are in campaign for some reason, or like tear gas grenade and gas mask.Then you start execution and watch the new way your team getting slaugthered in some wacky way on the first minute, then beat remaining mission as a lone wounded machine gunner, slumbering with broken legs and getting through by abusing leaning, which is how I did pre-last mission. Actually, that was slightly fun. But only for once.But really, the main reason to recommend it is the lack of alternatives. No other tactical FPS outside of Rainbow Six has detailed planning, as far as I am aware! So it's sad that Ubisoft wasted this part. New R6 games are still nice, but should have kept feature that was making franchise unique.Not as sad as lack of SWAT4 on Steam though.And for epic main theme that overloads nostalgia.

												I love this game. This game was one of my very first gaming experiences. Before Neopets. Before Pokemon. Before my PS1 and Xbox. Before Warcraft 3 and Diablo and all the other good stuff. I used to play this all the time with my dad, and as such constitutes some of my fondest childhood memories.Anyway, let's dive right in.This game has technical issues. The menus are locked to 800x600 (?) resolution, though the game itself supports much higher resolutions. It did 1080p just fine for me. However, due to the different resolutions, your resolution will fluctuate whenever you enter/leave the menus. Kind of annoying, but no big deal. You better get used to the low resolution though, because you'll be spending a lot of time in the planning menu. Which brings me to my next point...This is not your typical action FPS. It's relatively slow paced and you spend a lot of time planning things out. There are 3 teams you can customize. You can outfit each team member with different armor, weapons, weapon attachments, various types of grenades, and various utility tools. During planning you can dictate where your teams go, how they go there, what they do when the reach there, etc.For example, you might want green and gold team to wait for your signal ("Alpha, go!") before they clear a particular room. - Want one team to throw a smoke and the other to throw a flashbang before doing storming the room? Done. - Locked door? No problem, tell them to breach it first.- Hostages? Throw some tear gas in. Don't worry, you can outfit your guys with gas masks.There is a ton of ways to complete missions. You can take control of a team as well, and co-ordinate with the other teams in clearing a level. AI sometimes spotty. On occasions the AI will get stuck bumping into one another, or they'll be looking in stupid directions while taking fire. Most of the time though the AI is quite capable. You'll see your teams moving in formation, covering for one another. They'll strafe into rooms. I've actually been saved by my AI companion more times than I can count, so they're certainly not a burden.There is auto-aim, but you can turn it off. You can also configure how sensitive you want the auto-aim to be.There is a lot of trial and error. Your plans will not work on the first try. You'll be going through the level halfway when one of your teams starts getting killed off. Then you'll go back to the planning stage and try to rectify the flaws in your master plan. Maybe green team should throw a smoke before storming this particular room. Maybe you should reposition gold team so that they can better cover fire for green team. This is as much a strategy game as it is an action one.Another this is that death is permanent. You have a roster of soldiers, and if they die during a mission, they will not be available for subsequent missions. This gives you an incentive to complete missions with minimum casualties. Soldiers can be wounded too, making them move slower and have slower reflexes. Wounded soldiers recover after a couple missions.This game is fantastic, but it's not for everyone. It can't really be compared to anything else on the market. Unfortunately the Rainbow Six series is no longer the tactical shooter it once was.

We can choose evryone from the beginning, we mustn't unlock them during the game. Then we equip our operatives.We change their uniform, weapons, gadgets and others. After equipping our team, we should have a plan. This is the most interesting thing in the game. We make checkpoints to our team. Our team will go to these checkpoints. Also we can point, where should operatives throw grenade, or where should they wait another team.After we are ready, we are going to the "battlefield". We can control EVERYONE in our teams. Usually on missions there are 2 or 3 teams. Usually you should kill all terrorists or rescue all hostages. Sometimes you should deactivate the bomb or  plant bugs in the computers. Terrorist die from 1 or 2 shots. But you also die from 1 or 2 shots, so this game is hard.The graphics are still good for our days. Yeah, not Crysis, but Raven Shield is from 2003! The controls in game are not comfortable, because there are a lot of options: open doors silently, order your teammates, change operative and etc.Also there is cool multiplayer. There is not a lot of players, but it is not hard to find them. Usually on servers you should eliminate all terrorists. Also in Gold Edition includes Athena Sword, short campaign with new objectives, operatives and new missions with time limit.This game is very cool, the best tactical FPS of all times. People who love such kind of games will love it. Other players should also try this game. And it's cheap - $5.99!

Hint, do not get shot.-When someone dies they die.  Even just being immobilized from injuries will cause someone to be unusable for the rest of the campaign.  Unlike many other games where you will be take an RPG to the face and when the fighting stops get right back up again like that was just a scratch.  -The computer AI is much better than the previous Rainbow Six games (especially friendly AI).  In an earlier Rainbow Six game I once sent a team of eight people to attack the enemy and they could not figure out how to open the first door.  Eventually the enemy became bored and opened the door where he casually shot and killed all eight members on my team.  No one on my team even fired a shot.  The AI in this game does not even have to be given orders.  They know to shoot bad guys and to defuse bombs that they pass.  -One of the worst things about the previous Rainbow six games was the stealth missions. 												This game was and is the pinnacle of tactical shooters, it was a serious improvement on the already amazing original Rainbow Six games and it was the last installment of the Rainbow Six series that kept the spirit of the original. Though I did enjoy them, The Rainbow Six Vegas games were a little watered down to cater to the casual gamer compared to Raven Shield and Athena Sword. In fact, I believe this was the last decent and truely "realistic" tactical FPS. There are tons of maps in this game that allow for play styles varying from precise, patient and meticulously planned long range engagements to savage, fast paced and adrenaline fueled Close Quarters Battle. There is a massive selection of weapons, attachments, class specific items and even ammunition types allowing the player to tailor their kit to their play style. The armory is bigger than any game that I can think of. Because of this, the replayability of this game is endless. While it continues to be surprisingly entertaining for a game released in 2003, it is beginning to show it's age and lacks some of the innovative features seen in modern games. The player cannot look down the iron sights of the weapons. Unless optics are mounted on the weapon, the right mouse button only causes a zoom effect. Also the graphics are a bit obsolete. The installation of the Ravenshield 2.0 mod fixes this, however, by improving textures and adding many of the features (including iron sights) that we as gamers have become accustomed to in the last decade. To summarize, if you haven't played this game and you crave a challenging, thinking man's tactical shooter over the mindless run and gun FPS' you get these days you need this in your Steam library. If I can play this game consistently for over a decade without it getting old, I'm pretty sure you can get at least 100 hours out of it. Do yourself a favor and pull the trigger on this one, you won't regret it.

												The last real Rainbow Six game. I'm not saying this due to opinion. The name 'Rainbow Six', in the Tom Clancy universe, refers to the leader of the multi-national counter-terrorism SOF 'Rainbow'. In every Rainbow Six up to this one (original, Rogue Spear, Covert Ops), you take that role; assigning team members to squads, choosing each member's loadout, creating a plan for each team to carry out during the course of each mission. Then you can either spectate or take control of one of the teams. You really can't even compare or argue the Rainbow Six games that came out after this because they are basically a different genre with different fans.Post-Rainbow Six 3 (Lockdown, Vegas, Vegas 2, etc.) you only take control of a single protaganist throughout the entire game. You can't plan out the mission because the missions are linear and setpiece-focused, much like traditional FPS games. Your health regenerates in later games, and they have no wounding system. And while the Vegas games were still fun and you were still a member of Rainbow, you did not assume the position of the commander, Rainbow Six, in these games. And unfortunately, no big-name developer has made a game simliar to the old school Rainbow Six games in well over a decade.

Before each mission you may chose from a range of multi-national Rainbow Operatives to accompany you on a mission. Each operative has his/her specialty - be it alertness, stealth, leadership or skills with various equipment from breaching charges to sniper support to clearing rooms in close-quarters combat. It is up to you to decide each member's loadout (primary, secondary, type of ammunition, accessories, armor type, etc.,) You may chose to go in with a single squad or split up into 3 separate squads. Then comes the fun part - mission planning: drawing up a master plan takes time and dedication to carrying out a successful mission with zero casualties. Doing so you can rely on your fellow squad members to carry out your plans perfectly automatically - while you are sweeping the basement another squad that you assembled will sweep the roof for you, according to plan. But beware, everything relies on perfection.

												The Last decent Tom Clancy Title. This game was the absolute apex of brilliance when it came out. I remember taking the journey to GAME in Wimbledon with my mate to buy it the day it came out. My PC simply wouldn't run it at the time, so we took turns in having a life each. on his PC. We both digested the manual on the train back to his house and both watched the progress bar patiently as it installed from DVD.Little did we know at the time that this game would form such a grip on our gaming lives and produce so many amazing nights of pure strategic fun and frustration. One fond memory was on Airport we hunted down the last Tango. Me and a mate we both stacked up on separate doors, in the upstairs above the hangar. He flashed and I ran in with pistol, we both dropped the tango on entry with syncronised double taps. Was perfect and still comes up in conversation when we meet for a beer to this day.The beauty of this game for me was the amount of firearms available, the MP5 A4 was amongst, and still is my favourite. You can run with it and fire in burst or full auto and still hit your target. Weapons ranging from SMG through to sniper rifles can be deployed on any mission. Flash bangs, smoke greanades, tear gas (don’t forget your mask), Breaching charges etc. A plethora of pistols and with differing calibers and even the ability to switch the ammunition type, FMJ or HP. Such a nice level of detail even down to armour loadouts heavy for protection light for speed low drag set ups.It is a little dated by todays standards both graphically and in terms of movement but the core game mechanics and play is still great with a bunch of your mates on comms. Still some really nice touches in there for such an ageing title. The ability to open doors bit by bit so you can drop a flash in the close it then open it when the bang detonates is amazing.You can still play the game via the in game browser, limited severs but still some hardcore players still linger, after all these years. I can’t even remember how many times I have come back to this game despite it’s glory days behind me. 												I've come around to this game after a few false starts. I definitely recommend getting the 2.0 mod for this game, as it's a vatst improvement over the original layout. On to the game: I'm sure you've heard this game takes place in two parts - planning and action. Both are incredibly well done and are borderline simulation territory, but definitely still very gamey. The AI is pretty good, but not perfect. You can tell your squad to go clear a room and sometimes they will bunch in the doorway, ignoring terrorists. Another favorite is missions where enemies may not be armed, but are trying to complete some objective (like deleting data from computers). Many times, the AI would be told to clear a room and ignore these enemies, leading to a mission failure. For this reason, I feel there are a few missions that are just bugged and don't reflect the base game (namely mission 11, where it's unclear what is causing a mission failure, as all weapons were silenced and all enemies were killed upon entering a room). For missions like these, it's nice to have access to the developer console and just 'completemission.' This game is far from perfect, but it's really fun when everything comes together. The Gold Edition comes with the expansions, too, so you get a lot (around 30 missions?) for your money. SWAT 3 and 4 are still my favs, but this has an addicting element to it, as well.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												Edit: Changing formatting of list.This game is my "Dark Souls". It's infuriating, it has complex controls, enemies are super tough, and even with the tutorial you still don't know every aspect and you'll die a lot. But god do I love this game.NOTE: I played like, the first level of Athena Sword and that's it. All I've played so far (mostly) is Raven Shield, which is the base game. I also played it with a mod called Raven Shield 2.0 (which you can find on moddb). I HIGHLY reccommend it, as it improved almost every aspect of the game by adding weapons, camo, ironsights, and adds nice little tweaks.PROS:+ For a early 2000's game, the graphics are decent. Not fantastic, but you won't be looking at the game and throwing up.+ The environments are very well detailed. Even rooms that are out of the way with nobody in them are still lovingly put together. Except for a few reused missions near the end, there don't seem to be many glaringly reused assets, and as you go to different places around the world they defintely put care into making you feel like you were there.+ Good arsenal of weapons, although some are clearly not as good as others. You'll likely stick with the same few weapons for your team every time you play, but the choices are nice.+ Tight shooting. Each weapon handles fairly well and as with real life, burst fire and semi-auto will take enemies out way faster than spraying. Playing with the mod adds ironsights, but in vanilla there are none, making it more akin to Counter Strike in how you aim (although you can still zoom in slightly).+ Great tactics. Planning out your entry is always worth your time, and failing a mission can, yes, feel like utter BS, but then you can go back and study where you went wrong. You tweak your plan, change this and that, and when you're finished your plan goes smooth as butter. Even if you don't use the planning screen and go in blind (which I've done for a few), you still have a good repetoire of on-site tactics at your disposal. Order your team to burst in a door guns blazing, or maybe soften them with flashbangs, or you can tell them to go in on command so you can hurry over to a good vantage point to aid them from a flanking position. Basically, if you liked the quick tactics of R6 Vegas and Vegas 2, you'll catch on quick here.+ As always with the early R6 games, the music is fantastic. You'll get pumped up for sure.MEH:~ The story is ok. Nothing special, just enough to keep you going in one direction.~ Limited movement. In the early R6 games you could mantle and climb, but here you can't even go up a 2 foot platform without finding stairs. You get used to it, though.~ Your team AI can be a mixed bag. Most of the time they're great, and they'll spot and kill enemies you didn't notice, and they have far better reactions than you (obviously, since they're not human!). A few times, though, they can get a bit irritating. (Minor Spoilers ahead, although I'll try to stay vague). There's a point where you go to stop some chemical weapons, and enemies in hazmat suits are the ones that activate them if you're spotted. Unfortunately, those hazmat dudes are "non combatants" and thus your team members dont target them! I lost that mission so many times because my team wouldn't open fire on those enemies, simply because those enemies weren't a real "threat" to us!~ While it has been updated to modern resolution settings, the main menu is still locked at like, 800x600 or something.CONS:- Enemy AI can be a pain. Missions with hostages can be suddenly lost because they open fire on hostages since they know you're here. Thing is, they /shouldn't/ know you're there. You'll have to be extra careful playing this game, because there WILL be times that you lost because of BS enemy AI.- Dated controls. Be sure to edit the controls before you start playing. The defaults are hallmarks of the old R6 games, back when FPS games didn't really have a "standard". Things like reload set to Z, Run set to Mouse2... yeah. Not a bad terrible thing, but when I played the first mission I freaked out because I had no idea what to do.- Little explanation of stats for players and weapons. What is "self control"? What is "stability"? I have no idea. Some make sense, like Stealth or Electronics, or Damage and Accuracy for weapons, but despite the game having many tooltips, they have none for those. I'm not a mind reader!So in conclusion, its great. I love it, despite the difficulty and obtuse-ness of the game. I won't give it a number rating (because how I might percieve, say for example, a 7/10 might be different for another person). I will just say that for 10 bucks, you can't go wrong with this. Quite a few missions, plus you can replay those maps plus a few more with different modes, which might give you an extra hour or two of fun. Again, I do suggest the Raven Shield 2.0 mod for this game, because it "modernizes" it in all the right ways.

												While I do not have an abundance of hours clocked on this game, I did have the disc when it came out in 2003. Since then, I have played that thing to death: memorizing enemy locations, the stats of certain characters, and the best weapons combinations. Why? Because not only does this game have excellent gameplay, but no matter how many times you beat it, you can always find better ways to play, or cooler ways to succeed.The positive aspects of the game are inherent to the gameplay - being a tactical shooter, Rainbow Six 3 (Raven Shield) with its expansions let you use maps to guide ally movements and actions. An example: I know that there is a hostage at the room on the right above the stairs. I can map Green Team, the group I have equipped with heavy assault rifles, to breach the double doors in the center while Red Team, with their silenced weapons, push through the exit in the back, cutting them off quickly. This all happens while I send Gold team to snipe from the runway, ensuring no tangos get the jump on us. We go on the call "Bravo."It's the most fun I have had playing a Tom Clancy Game.The negatives come only with the age of the game. It was made in 2003, so the graphics, compared to today, are sub-par. That also means the the AI is a little slow and flawed. Sometimes terrorists can pinpoint your position and pull off a headshot without ever knowing you were there, and sometimes your allies will walk into a full warehouse of badies walking backwards, continuing the slaughter. This can be incredibly aggravating, but these occurences are few and far between.You have a lot of freedom with gun customization, especially for a game of this particular era, and a lot of freedom with how you plan and execute your missions. This is a must play for any Tom Clancy fan. 8/10

Posted: December 25, 2015
												This is the benchmark for tactical shooters on the PC, and has yet to be surpassed by any other game. Raven Shield and the other original Rainbow 6/Rogue Spear games are true tactical counter-terrorism simulations, based on real weapons and tactics used in modern day counter terrorist operations. You plan your mission, you don't get to save during a mission, and it's one-shot and you're dead. No regenerating health, and when an operative dies it is final. I love Raven Shield because of the punishing difficulty, and emphasis on being the first to spot your opponent and quickly aim for the head. I think this is a good representation for close quarters combat, as close as you can get to real life. I love this game, and it's sad to see the Tom Clancy and Rainbow Six licenses being sold down the river. Everything after RVS and Athena Sword has been dumbed down garbage for the masses. Rainbow Six was never meant to appeal to the call of duty or counter strike crowd, it was in a class of its own. I got this game when it came out in 2003 and I just re-installed it, and it's as good as ever. I've beaten the single player 4 times, twice on elite, and it doesn't get any better than the feeling of successfully completing a mission with no fatalities. I have spent countless hours on multiplayer, which is also great too. I can only hope they make more games like this, because there are no modern games that come close to realism and tactical depth like Raven Shield does.

												The epitome of tactical first person shooter video games, and unfortunately the last of its kind. The gameplay of Rainbow Six 3 focuses heavily on the careful formulation and execution of player-made tactical plans in hypothetical scenarios, having players designate specific waypoints and commands to squads of soldiers in the game world (of which they also play the soldiers themselves after planning) in order to complete various objectives. While this may seem tiresome and mundane for players wanting instant and intense action (planning is optional), the reward for having a tactical plan execute successfully is extremely satisfying, considering the difficulty of the scenarios and the respective time taken to fully plan for them. Throw in a completely seamless multiplayer component and the thrills of planning tactical missions together with friends become unforgettably fun.

												Love this game SO much.  Controls 11/10, actually the best I've ever experienced.  There are a lot of tactical options, but somehow they made it all intuitive to where you can just do the training, and jump right into the first missions and probably beat it on the easiest level.  Gameplay 10/10.  Maps are well thought out, and immersive.  Enemies act how you think they would act for a given difficulty level.  Example:  They don't just mercilessly mow you down right out of the gate on easy, and on hard they pretty much do lol.  When I get killed, it's always been because I missed a guy hiding, wasn't patient enough, etc.  I have yet to feel like the game is cheating, using cheap exploits, etc.Story...  2/10 It seems to be be pretty rudimentary.  Elite strike force, assault, recon, or infiltration missions with brief backstory ("Terrorists are occupying an oil refinery unless their buddy gets released.  Go kill them.").  I have not finished the base game yet, so maybe there is something more to come here, and shooters just didn't have plots as a general rule in the good old days, but it would have been nice to flesh it out a little more.  It is what it is.  The game is fantastic, but don't play it expecting a Skyrim type story.  It's purely a tactical shooter as far as I can tell at this point.Online play - Have not tried it yet, though I read in forums some people still play.  Will try it after I finish the solo campaigns.DLC - 10/10.  Comes with one expansion (Athena Sword), and another is free to download, although it was a bugger to get installed (Iron Wrath).  Honestly, this is a game I see myself playing every map in every expansion too, so I'm happy for the extra content.Overall - 10/10.  I find myself not really caring about the story while I am playing, because it's that tactical rush, and the controls and game play are so well thought out it's HIGHLY addictive.  I compare the combat to the last game I played, Skyrim Legendary Edition.  I constantly felt like Skyrim abused the somewhat clunky and sluggish combat mechanics unfairly, was TOTALLY unbalanced in parts, although I loved it.  I never get that feeling with R63.  You CAN beat the missions if you know what you're doing.  Sure, that occasionally means level memorization and trial and error, but it's actually pretty fun, and I've even replayed some missions just to see if I could do them better.  This game is a GEM, and I find myself wishing all games were like this, and not caring about the somewhat dated graphics.  Actually, I kind like the graphics.  They don't get in the way or slow down my PC, very functional and kind of a retro appeal.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED especially at $4.99.  Some of the other trash on here for $4.99 makes me laugh in comparison.

												Raven Shield is what many (myself included, if I'm honest) consider to be the best Rainbow Six game, as all the following entries in the series either fail at realism, (Lockdown) or straight-up take the 'arcade' route. (Vegas)It's often compared to the likes of Counter-Strike, and I'd honestly say that it's better. This is because it adds a lot more to the table in terms of weapons, game modes, maps, decent AI opponents and team mates, as well as allowing you to perform more actions; as an example, you're able to 'fluidly' open doors so you can silently open it a crack to peep through, just swing it open, or even put a breaching charge on it.In terms of weapons/gadgets you can use, other than having literally a mountain of guns to pick from, (although I always say the FNC and Steyr AUG are the best ;) ) ranging from assault rifles, sniper rifles, sub-machine guns, shotguns, light machine guns and pistols (including automatic pistols), there are a whole load of grenades and other equip-able items you can pick from. For example, there are of course your typical frag and flashbang grenades in the game, but there are also CS teargas (and gasmasks you can take to counter this) and smoke grenades. Not to mention the various other explosives and utilities, such as claymores + remote detonators (no magic hostile presence-detecting ones like in other games), C4 explosives, heartbeat detectors and many more.Also, the iron-sight haters won't have a problem with R6 3:RS either, as they've still got the good ol' zoom - which shouldn't be an issue for those who dislike the zoom, as there are plenty of choices with scopes of varying types, as well as other attachments for your weapons.So yeah, essentially if you want to play a realistic and fun shooter with loads of different tactics and choices, get this!

It is outdated yes, but the gameplay makes you forget all about it as it is just amazing to be an officer for Rainbow Six.This is the last best game in the series (Still waiting for the cod version of Rainbow Six, aka Siege), and is a must if you love S.W.A.T. 4 or any of the Rainbow Six games before Siege. You get to decide movement, actions, aggressiveness and order other teams/your team to wait until you give the command to move or the other team is ready. The enemy A.I. is not great, they react poorly to sounds and friendly corpses. If you run, they'll hear you through floors, if you shoot, they'll only hear you if your standing next to them. If you spray, you'll miss your target and probably die. Bullets are deadly, meaning you'll die in just a few bullets even with the heavy gear. You're not a bullet sponge, be careful around corners.Leaning, leaning around corners is REALLY important here, and they've done a fantastic job with that. There is the standard q and e to lean, but also ctrl. With controll, you can lean how ever you want, it makes taking cover a much easier job than in other shooters.RS3 has the standard gamemodes, Terrorist Hunt (killing terrorists), Hostage Rescue, Bomb defusal and so on. However, in RS3, hostages can and will be shot by Ts, if not careful. If they're alerted, they'll shot them without hesitation. 												Rainbow Six 3, like most of Tom Clancy's titles, is a squad-based tactical shooter with a lot of depth. This game favors tactics over action, and you will spend hours planning out each mission before actually playing it. Before a mission, you can choose who goes on what team (Alpha, Charlie, etc.), choose their loadouts (a lot of weapons to choose from, each with their own advantages and disadvantages), and plan out the mission waypoint by waypoint. Once you are comfortable with how the planning stage works, you can coordinate attacks from multiple angles, give go-codes to execute orders, set the rules of engagement, and so on. The game gives you the option to either play through the mission or watch the AI do what you have told them to do. It's a really nice option, because it's basically two totally different styles of gameplay. You can play it as a strategy game, being the man calling the shots, or play it through the eyes of a Rainbow operative. Pick this one up.

												Rainbow Six 3, like most of Tom Clancy's titles, is a squad-based tactical shooter with a lot of depth. This game favors tactics over action, and you will spend hours planning out each mission before actually playing it. Before a mission, you can choose who goes on what team (Alpha, Charlie, etc.), choose their loadouts (a lot of weapons to choose from, each with their own advantages and disadvantages), and plan out the mission waypoint by waypoint. Once you are comfortable with how the planning stage works, you can coordinate attacks from multiple angles, give go-codes to execute orders, set the rules of engagement, and so on. The game gives you the option to either play through the mission or watch the AI do what you have told them to do. It's a really nice option, because it's basically two totally different styles of gameplay. You can play it as a strategy game, being the man calling the shots, or play it through the eyes of a Rainbow operative. Pick this one up.

												Great game, one of my all time favourites. Its worth buying at sale time for $5. You should get about 40 - 80 hours out of it. Be sure to have a look at gameplay and reviews to see what its like (apparently is quite different to the newer Rainbow Six games) in that it is very tactical, think SWAT 3 and SWAT 4.Also, in terms of multiplayer I cannot comment as I haven't played multiplayer.Single player is great. You get about 17 missions in a campaign and 8 skirmish maps to play on for Rainbow Six 3, and a campaign with about 8 missions and 8 skirmish maps for the Athena Sword add on pack included in this Gold Edition. Also, you can download for free the Iron Wrath expanision pack which adds even more missions and maps (there is plenty of info out there about how to get this going for the Steam verison).The missions are usually about killing or terrorists, saving hostages and diffusing bombs in a tactical way. A fair bit of time is spent planning and replaying the missions and this may be a turn off for those who just want action. A few other modes are available including terrorist hunt, hostage rescue and lone wolf that add to replayability. There are about 60 odd guns in the game with everything from submachine guns to sniper rifles plus things like CS gas and stun grenades.Downsides:- A fair bit of time is spent planning as opposed to playing eg a usual mission will take about 10 minutes of planning and 5 minutes of action but expect to be replaying the mission and doing the planning phase plenty of times over.- Enemy and friendly AI can be really bad at times.- Old game (2004?) so graphics aren't going to be great.- I'd say buy it at sale time for a big discount as at $10usd you may feel ripped off.

												A realistic game, if you can call a shooter that. Exteremely quick (and in the campaing, permanent) death, slow movement and the ability to carry only one rifle, one sidearm and 6 grenades at most are somewhat realistick but don't believe it when people call this game hyper realistic. The game's immersion is broken easily by things like hip-fire reticlespread applying even when using a scope. The relatively braindead ai is a known problem, but it doesnt matter because the enemy isn't supposed to do anything else than react to hearing gunfire and fire at you when they see you. Your teammates on the other hand do just fine, because they do as they are told and don't improvise anything stupid. Except when they decide to fall off from a ladder and die, forcing you to restart the mission. The pseudo-randomized enemy placement and the sometimes unreliable teammate ai make sure that however well you plan your missions, you will need at least one retry before you get the desired no casualty -run. The fact that planning your mission can take up a good 20-30 minutes and executing the plan take a rough 5 min depending on mission. That is, if you get it working on the first try. Fixing your plan between retries can easily take up a cumulative 30min unless you have to redo the plan altogether. All that combined and you can waste an evenening just trying to complete that one hostage recue. The game can be very frustrating on the other hand very satisfying when you finally complete that one mission. Despite everything negative I said about the game, it is in my opinion an enjoyable experience. Just as a word of warning: This is not an fps Dark Souls, in this game you move a lot slower but die a lot faster. You can end up 6 feet below in a literal heartbeat. Have fun.

												If you ever felt like FPS games today were just shooting galleries, then you should probably pick up this game.I was there, I fought the war against Supersoldier-Nazi-Terrorists from the future. I played Rainbow Six on the console and I beat it once... only once. The game has you playing against Supersoldier-Nazi-terrorists from the future, seriously you should watch the intro... that's the only way I can explain the story, for America. You thought CoD: World at War was deep? This game is deeper. This game is about fighting for America.... in Switzerland.As a fun, challenging game, Rainbow Six has you taking control of up to three teams and with you planning out their movements along with placing checkpoints yourself. As you start the mission and having your teams following their pre-constructed paths, they will all inevitably die to the incredible aim of the Super-soldier-Nazi-Terrorists (I always manually take control of teams and members to make sure no one dies). Still, it was much easier than the console version which basically had you and three other guys (or four, I forgot) with no backup and running into a whole lotta crossfires and traps. Men get blown to pieces by Terrorists with their grenades and you will get cutdown mercilessly by molten metal fired from the barrels of hidden guns.This game is easier, with the ability to pre-plan your movements and the ability to take control of multiple teams and team members. This game isn't about twitch shooting or aim, it's about precaution. Precaution as in, "Don't run in clear view of a sniper you dumb♥♥♥♥." The game doesn't hold your hand and requires a lot of luck at times, but in all honesty it is how you plan and how you plan to execute it along with a plan B if everything goes wrong. If you find firefights too frustrating, the game even allows aim assist (the equivalent of aimbotting). You have to anticipate the ♥♥♥♥♥iest situations and how to deal with them. I like the weapons, most of them have different stats and have situational advantages during some missions. However, shotguns are completely inaccurate unless you've got a scope on it (which I find strange).Team members also have stats and it somewhat rewards you for keeping them alive. The more men survive through missions the better stats they get, so they can aim better, run better, etc. Always keep stealth team members with other stealth team members otherwise the other dudes in the group will give them away. Having a balanced number of team members and organizing their equipment is actually.... fun.I get to choose what weapon to use, what grenades I want and who I want with me. Yeah, the game can get frustrating at times, but mostly it is your fault if you lose. You have to observe enemy movement, study their patrol paths and watch them intently then plan actions accordingly. You can't run in every room throwing a smoke grenade because of your limited supplies. The heartbeat sensors actually make the game easier because you can see where terrorists are going through the walls and doors (console game had thermal vision). You're never supposed to fight the enemy head-on not unless you've put yourself in a advantageous situation (i.e. smoked room enemy can't see you, flash bang renders terrorists unable to fight back etc.).Multiplayer is also a blast, if you ever get to play just use your Uplay account username and password. I had to play with three or so other guys against hordes of terrorists in the other room with us throwing tear gas this way and that. There are plenty of wonderful pvp and pve levels that has you killing terrorists on top of buildings, in cities, on boats and wherever the strange and unique level designs take you. Did I tell you I got to fight Nazi Terrorists... IN SPACE?!Go buy it but keep in mind it's tough difficulty and sometimes frustrating nature.

												If you ever felt like FPS games today were just shooting galleries, then you should probably pick up this game.I was there, I fought the war against Supersoldier-Nazi-Terrorists from the future. I played Rainbow Six on the console and I beat it once... only once. The game has you playing against Supersoldier-Nazi-terrorists from the future, seriously you should watch the intro... that's the only way I can explain the story, for America. You thought CoD: World at War was deep? This game is deeper. This game is about fighting for America.... in Switzerland.As a fun, challenging game, Rainbow Six has you taking control of up to three teams and with you planning out their movements along with placing checkpoints yourself. As you start the mission and having your teams following their pre-constructed paths, they will all inevitably die to the incredible aim of the Super-soldier-Nazi-Terrorists (I always manually take control of teams and members to make sure no one dies). Still, it was much easier than the console version which basically had you and three other guys (or four, I forgot) with no backup and running into a whole lotta crossfires and traps. Men get blown to pieces by Terrorists with their grenades and you will get cutdown mercilessly by molten metal fired from the barrels of hidden guns.This game is easier, with the ability to pre-plan your movements and the ability to take control of multiple teams and team members. This game isn't about twitch shooting or aim, it's about precaution. Precaution as in, "Don't run in clear view of a sniper you dumb♥♥♥♥." The game doesn't hold your hand and requires a lot of luck at times, but in all honesty it is how you plan and how you plan to execute it along with a plan B if everything goes wrong. If you find firefights too frustrating, the game even allows aim assist (the equivalent of aimbotting). You have to anticipate the ♥♥♥♥♥iest situations and how to deal with them. I like the weapons, most of them have different stats and have situational advantages during some missions. However, shotguns are completely inaccurate unless you've got a scope on it (which I find strange).Team members also have stats and it somewhat rewards you for keeping them alive. The more men survive through missions the better stats they get, so they can aim better, run better, etc. Always keep stealth team members with other stealth team members otherwise the other dudes in the group will give them away. Having a balanced number of team members and organizing their equipment is actually.... fun.I get to choose what weapon to use, what grenades I want and who I want with me. Yeah, the game can get frustrating at times, but mostly it is your fault if you lose. You have to observe enemy movement, study their patrol paths and watch them intently then plan actions accordingly. You can't run in every room throwing a smoke grenade because of your limited supplies. The heartbeat sensors actually make the game easier because you can see where terrorists are going through the walls and doors (console game had thermal vision). You're never supposed to fight the enemy head-on not unless you've put yourself in a advantageous situation (i.e. smoked room enemy can't see you, flash bang renders terrorists unable to fight back etc.).Multiplayer is also a blast, if you ever get to play just use your Uplay account username and password. I had to play with three or so other guys against hordes of terrorists in the other room with us throwing tear gas this way and that. There are plenty of wonderful pvp and pve levels that has you killing terrorists on top of buildings, in cities, on boats and wherever the strange and unique level designs take you. Did I tell you I got to fight Nazi Terrorists... IN SPACE?!Go buy it but keep in mind it's tough difficulty and sometimes frustrating nature.

												I was already familiar with the original Xbox version, though my memory of it isn't detailed, and the semi-modern Vegas games. Both Vegas games have their fair share of problems, including bad third-person cover systems, enemies that spawn behind you, nonsensical instant deaths, sound glitches, and (in the case of Vegas 2) a sprint function that makes the multiplayer feel more like a slower CoD than a tactical shooter. Everyone on the internet told me that RS3 is better in every way, the definitive tactical shooter.They were wrong.Rainbow Six 3 has enemies that can't hear gunfire from 10 feet away or see their friends die right in front of them, but they are quite capable of seeing through brick walls and hearing footsteps from across the room. On more than one occasion, I died at random, one time by an explosion that didn't have an accompanying grenade or terrorist.The weapon selection is decent, though I find it hard to find anything to be excited about. You can customize your weapons by choosing between features like an extended mag, a scope, or a silencer. Some weapons have multiple ammo types which don't really matter in a terrorist hunt. Character customization does not exist, but it isn't really needed.Movement is slow, but that's to be expected. What isn't expected is the painfully slow sidestep. Having manual control over the motion of opening doors, crouching, and leaning is interesting and will probably be useful for hardcore players. The most welcome function is the ability to lean around corners. That's what tactical shooters are: Q and E to lean. Not recommended.

												This game is the benchmark against which I measure all other tactical shooters and trust me when I tell you that practically no other game that has come out after Raven Shield measures up to it. SWAT 4 is very close but RVS comes out on top. In Rainbow Six 3 you take control of an international counter-terrorist unit called Rainbow and your job is to prevent terrorists from doing whatever it is that they are trying to do. To achieve this you use the powerful mission planner to plan your mission to the finest detail, coordinating up to three teams or a maximum of eight operatives. The planner will let you do anything you need to do to get the job done. For example you can set up go-codes to clear a room from multiple directions simultaneously. You can define how the teams make entry into a room: should they breach the door using a breaching charge? Should they throw in a flashbang or gas grenade before entering the room? You get the picture. You can also define the rules of engagement and movement speed of your teams for any waypoint. You can command them to be stealthy and only fire when fired upon for example or you can make them run and shoot on sight if you need to cover ground quickly to get to a hostage or bomb. The planner is awesome.After you've finished planning your mission you can equip your teams any way you want. There's a lot of gear to choose from. There are light, medium and heavy armor and they affect your stealthiness and speed. Light armor is quiet and stealthy but does not offer much protection. Medium is a great balance and heavy armor looks kind of like riot gear and gives you extra protection but all your actions like switching weapons, turning around etc take a little longer to complete. You'll also be louder when you move. Then there are the weapons. There's a huge selection of SMG's, assault rifles, shotguns, sniper rifles, pistols, machine pistols, grenades etc. There is also a selection of tactical gear like heartbeat sensors, demolition kits (to speed up defusing of bombs), lockpicking kits etc. You can equip each individual operative however you want.When you get in the mission itself you can switch between teams and operatives to control them at any time or you can stick to controlling your guy and let the AI do it's job according to the plan you've set out for those teams. The friendly AI is very good. The trailing guy will cover the rear of your team and they are very aware of their surroundings and they are accurate as well when firing. They're also good at clearing rooms. They get through the door quickly and each operative will cover their own area of responsibility in the room. You can command your AI team mates on the fly to perform actions like clearing rooms using breaching charges, flashbangs, gas grenades etc. You can also command them to pick locks, defuse bombs or to escort hostages out of harms way. You can perform these actions yourself also. The damage modelling is pretty awesome. You suffer different effects depending on where you're shot (if you're lucky enough to only get wounded that is). Your aim suffers a lot if you get hit in your arm for example. You can't run and your walking slows if you get hit in the leg and so on. Good mission planning is crucial because you want your team members to survive the mission so you can use them again. You have a limited number of operatives of varying skill levels and specialties and if they get wounded they will need time to heal before you can use them again. If they die you lose them for the rest of the campaign. The sounds are awesome too.The enemy AI could be a little better although there's nothing in their behaviour that would get really annoying during gameplay. Sometimes one of them will drop a grenade as he dies and after it goes off you can hear "huh, what was that?" from the next room as if you can't tell when a frag grenade goes off in the hallway. They're pretty good at coming to investigate noises and stuff like that and they will use cover and get backup if you miss your shot and they get away. On the hardest setting they can be pretty brutal and it's tough to complete missions without any casualties to your team unless you've planned it perfectly.After you get the hang of the game you can get online and you'll find there are still people playing. You can play adversarial modes or you can play the campaign missions co-operatively with your friends, coordinating take downs etc. using teamspeak for example. Multiplayer requires a ubi.com account and the game does lack voice comms of it's own but those are not big minuses.The game is still every bit as awesome as it was when it came out. The graphics are a bit dated but it will run like a dream in very high resolutions and with ridiculous amounts of AA and AF on. With those kinds of settings it looks pretty good. Also you can get a mod called Raven Shield 2.0 that will enhance the realism of the game to even higher levels adding things like iron sights and it also has higher resolution textures for the operators and terrorists enhancing the look of the game. I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of tactical gaming and has somehow missed this gem. This is the best tactical shooter out there.

												Where do I even start with this one?      It's the gold standard of the Rainbow Six series for starters. The game is arguably the funnest tactical shooter ever and this is the game people point to when asked about a more tactical and professional feeling Rainbow Six game than the action games like Rainbow Six: Vegas. Being a game from 2003, the graphics look a bit rough, though that doesn't hurt the gameplay at all. You play as a sort of commander for the elite, international, blacker-than-black ops team Rainbow. Rainbow specializes in counter-terror and hostage rescue missions and are deployed when needed around the globe. This means that the levels take place across a variety of settings. You'll go from saving dignitaries in the Swiss alps to foiling bank robbers in London to clearing a mansion of baddies in the Cayman Islands. This keeps things unique and interesting throughout the game.      Each mission has a set pattern to it. You start by learning about the situation from Rainbow Six, the leader of Rainbow, and the other advisors with him. You then go to the team room where you select which operatives are going out on the mission, select their guns, armor, and other equipment, and choose what teams they'll be on. Then you go to the bread and butter of the game: the planning room. You are given a blueprint of the area and tasked with creating a plan for the teams to follow that will result in a successful mission. The planning system does take a bit of time to master but once the get the hang of things you'll find that the planning system is robust and customizable with a great depth to it. Once you have a plan created you can choose what team you'll be leading, in first person shooter style, through the action phase of the mission.      The action isn't as fast-paced as other games, but the methodical and tactical way that you can move through the area is unique, very enjoyable, and by no means boring. The action gameplay can shift from stealth to sychronized takedowns to all out gunfighting at a moments notice. The operatives and the terrorists all react realistically to bullets, meaning they die near-instantly. If that sounds too tough for the more tactical-minded gamers, you can also choose to observe the plan from a third-person flying camera and let the A.I take control of the operatives on the mission. You'll invariably find your plans don't always succeed, but there's much fun to be had from tweaking your plan until the teams move through the level like a well-oiled machine; to qoute the A-Team, "I love it when a plan comes together." On a related note there are pre-made plans that you can load in if you find the planning system too much to handle or are frustrated with repeated failures.    The last great feature of the game is the custom mission option. This gives you access to all the maps that you've unlocked in the campaign and some that are only available in this mode and allows you to create a random mission from a good amount of mission types. Replaying story missions, terrorist hunt, hostage rescue, and lone wolf wherein you are alone and needing to get to the extraction point. The custom mission feature garuntees that you won't get bored with this game. Add to all the goodness explained already the fact that there's still a thriving modding community keeping this game fresh and adding better graphics and more gameplay to this already massive game and you've got a shining gem of the tactical shooter genre that still hasn't been topped in the decade that it has been out.

												tl;dr This game is a tactical shooter, so it may not be for everyone. It can still be fun to play with people, granted they know what they are doing. The game may have some technical flaws (it being old). If you want to play good old Rainbow Six without wrestling with the Original's engine, pick this one up.Rainbow Six 3 is a squad based, tactical shooter. This game allows you to take control of the elite counterterrorism unit RAINBOW (yes, that's the name of the unit).This game is not something you rush into. You need tactics. The game has an entire planning phase where you can modify how each group of operatives moves. You can tell them to wait on your mark, then when you give the go-code, open the door and flash through it.Multiplayer still works, however you have to have a uPlay account. You could try lan or hamachi, but I didn't test that. The game has a mutlitude of weapons and armor for you to choose. You can use silenced smgs with flashbangs and go full on stealth, or use 50.cal snipers and M4's with frag grenades to go all out.This game is also not as easy as your usual FPS. You get a maximum of 1-3 hits before your dead. Everyone follows this rule. Once someone's dead, they can no longer be chosen, so make sure your teammates don't die.The game also has some mechanics that I've never seen any other FPS have before, or after. These are the fluid lean and door opening. Using the mouse, you can adjust your character to lean at many other angles other than one. Fluid door opening allows you to open doors halfway, a tiny bit, or just enough to let a grenade through.That said, the game has flaws. The planning stage is locked at ~800x600 (the game isn't but the menus are). The game can sometimes be a bit hard to get into, and you may have to do levels over and over to make sure your preferred teammates didn't die. This game is way different than alot of FPSes out today (Call of Duty, Team Fortress, and Battlefield aren't very comparable. Counter-Strike is a bit comparable, but still has alot of differences).
